options: Advise him to speak to Dr Jones directly
Reassure him that an early diagnosis would not have altered his wife's prognosis
Advise him to publicise his concerns in the local paper
Advise him to contact the Health Service Ombudsman
Advise him to make a written complaint to the surgery
questions:
A 69-year-old man presents to surgery. He states he is unhappy that Dr Jones, one of your colleagues at the surgery, took so long diagnosing his wife with Parkinson's disease.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
When patients or their relatives feel that they have received inadequate care the first step is to try and achieve local resolution. Speaking to the health care professionals involved can often resolve any misunderstandings. If this does not resolve the issue the next step[ is for the patient or family to make a formal written complaint.

If local resolution fails then the next step is to involve a more central body such as the Health Service Ombudsman. All complaints should be acknowledged and not played down, regardless of whether it has altered a patient's long-term prognosis.

Advising a patient to contact the local paper is not likely to result in a resolution to the situation.

options: Treat the patient first, despite him coming in later than other people, as he is causing others distress
Inform the patient that you will not treat him
Ask security to keep an eye on the patient
Ask the ward matron to go and calm him down
Inform the patient that the team is doing their best to get through all of the patients as quickly as possible and request that he tries to calm down in the meantime
questions:
You are a doctor who is working in the emergency department. A patient in the waiting area is drunk and is being very loud and aggressive due to the long waiting times. Other people in the waiting area are feeling uncomfortable.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this question are those of staff and patient safety and dealing with difficult patients.

The most appropriate option in this scenario is informing the patient that the team is doing their best to get through all of the patients as quickly as possible and requesting that the patient tries to calm down in the meantime (5). This is the best option as it is proactive in that you are providing an explanation for the delay in waiting time and attempting to de-escalate the patient.

Asking security to keep an eye on the patient (3) is a wise decision. Security will be able to help deal with the patient in case of further escalation of his mood. This, however, is a less preferable option to option 5 as you are not actually doing anything to de-escalate the situation in this response.

Asking the ward matron to calm the patient down (4) could be a good option, in that it attempts to de-escalate the situation. However, you are 'passing the buck' so to speak, and placing the matron in a situation where she may be assaulted.

Treating the patient first (1) and informing the patient that you will not treat him (2) are both inappropriate responses to this scenario. Treating the patient first (2) means that patients who came in before him, and patients who are more unwell, may have to wait for treatment, which potentially places patients' safety at risk. This is preferable to informing the patient that you will not treat him, which is the least appropriate response. The patient is in the accident and emergency department and, although they have been aggressive, they may have a life-threatening condition that you are unaware of at that moment. The patient needs to be seen by a doctor and you are risking patient safety by refusing to treat him.

options: Offer to review her twice a day to alleviate her concerns
Offer to spend some time with her after the ward round to listen to her concerns
Phone your consultant and ask them to see the patient
Inform them of the patient advice and liaison service (PALS)
Take no action given her clinical improvement
questions:
You are working as a junior doctor on a respiratory ward. A patient who has been admitted for the past 5 days with an exacerbation of COPD is angry and tells you that they wish to make a complaint against you. They feel that they haven't been reviewed as often as they feel they should have been. Looking at the notes you see that they have been reviewed at least once a day and has been improving clinically.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
From the scenario, it seems that this patient's complaint is unreasonable. Ideally, patients would have multiple contacts with their health care team throughout the day but this is not realistic given the time demands in modern clinical practice.

The best option is to discuss the concerns with the patient (B). This may be enough to reassure the patient that you are engaged in her clinical care and hence resolve the complaint.

The next best option is to involve your consultant (C).

Advising a patient how to make a complaint (D) is appropriate if you can't resolve her concerns yourself. PALS are able to advocate for a patient on their behalf.

Offering to change your clinical practice to placate her (A) is a poor option as this could adversely affect other aspects of your practice - you only have limited amounts of time.

Taking no action (E) is a poor option.

options: Tell her it is dangerous to have another termination and advise her not to go ahead on health grounds
Make an appointment for her to see a colleague due to your reservations
Refer for termination of pregnancy + arrange an appointment to discuss contraception
Tell her you want no part in it but give her the details for the British Pregnancy Advisory Service
Tell her you will not arrange a termination as she has had so many in the past
questions:
A 34-year-old woman presents to surgery. She is 12 weeks pregnant and requests a termination of pregnancy as she says she couldn't cope with another child. From your records, she has three children aged 3, 6 and 10 years and in the past has had five previous terminations, including one at 17 weeks. In the past, she has refused to use contraception due to her perceived risks of side effects.

You have in the past referred people for terminations and have no ethical objections in general. However, you are troubled by the number she has had previously and her reluctance to use contraception.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Firstly it should be acknowledged that no doctor should have to participate/refer/perform a termination of pregnancy if they have ethical objections, for example on religious grounds. They do however have to refer on to another doctor who may help the patient.

In this scenario the doctor has previously referred the patients for terminations but is faced with a situation where they may feel the patient is not taking sufficient responsibility for their own health, i.e. The doctor has no ethical objection to abortion but is troubled/angered by the situation. The key to the answer is to act in a non-judgemental way - if you have referred the patient previously then the only reason you would not refer now is because you have made a judgement about the patient.

The next best option is to refer her to a colleague because of your reservations. Telling her 'you want no part in it' is unprofessional but at least you are referring her to someone who may help her. Refusing to arrange the termination is not performing your duty to help a patient and the worst option is to tell her that it is dangerous to go ahead on health grounds as this is not correct.

options: Refuse to discuss the issue and ask your registrar to handle the situation.
Explain that it is most likely the patient detached the tube accidentally.
Tell them that the tubing became detached.

questions:
You are a ST doctor on the respiratory ward and you have been called to see an unwell patient. When you see the patient they are saturating at 38% and you realise that their high flow oxygen tube on their mask has become detached. After reattaching the tubing the patient recovers. Later on that day their family approach you and ask you why their relative became so unwell.

See below.Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
As with giving any information it is always best to find out what the relatives know about the situation (4). It is vital that doctors are honest when things go wrong (3). This issue can be dealt with initially by a ST doctor and therefore it is not appropriate to delegate this task (1). Blaming the patient is a poor choice and is not a good option (2). Pleading ignorance is lying to the relatives as you know what caused the situation and is the least appropriate choice (5).

The GMC acknowledge that it is important primarily for learning to recognise mistakes in order to improve practice. This should also prevent the feeling of shame which is negative and not helpful when things go wrong.

options: Leave theatre and ask her husband to complete a consent form then examine the patient
Examine the patient using the implied consent rule
Examine the patient using the implied consent rule but tell patient following the operation as matter of courtesy
Refuse to examine the patient
Complete a consent form on her behalf then examine the patient
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in gynaecology and are helping the consultant in theatre with the morning list. A 43-year-old woman is having a hysterectomy for menorrhagia secondary to large, bulky fibroids. You only met the patient briefly on the ward round this morning. The consultant invites you to perform a PV examination just prior to the surgery commencing.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC gives the following guidance relating to this scenario:
'You must obtain consent prior to anaesthetisation, usually in writing, for the intimate examination of anaesthetised patients.'
Consent should always be obtained before performing intimate examinations. Whilst implied consent can justify the taking of a routine history or examination it cannot be used in this situation. By performing a vaginal examination the ST1 doctor is not contributing to the operation. The best option is therefore to refuse to examine the patient

If you do perform a vaginal examination it is best to be honest and discuss it with the patient following the operation.

Her husband cannot consent for her and neither can you!

options: Delegate the task to the practice nurse

Advise the patient about relaxation techniques
Finish your surgery then go and see the patient

questions:
You are a GP registrar. During a busy morning clinic the receptionists phone you. They have triaged an urgent home visit request for a man with metastatic prostate cancer who is in severe pain that is described as being 'all over my body'. You are aware of the patient as he was recently discussed at the monthly palliative care meeting. You are running 20 minutes behind already and are not due to finish clinic for another two hours.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at how urgently a patient with severe pain should be seen. In most similar scenarios, for example a patient who phones due to chest pain, the most appropriate response is phone for an ambulance. However, in the palliative setting this may not be appropriate.

Speaking to the partners at the practice is the best option. They will be experienced in managing such situations and may know the patient well. They may also not be running as far behind as you are and may be able to visit sooner.

The next best response is therefore to go immediately and see the patient at home. Whilst this will inevitably have knock-on effects to your surgery the alternative is to leave the patient is pain.

Whilst the practice nurse is not the best person to assess the situation she may be at least able to gather more information.

Relaxation techniques are unlikely to be effective in the context of breakthrough pain.

options: Complete an incident form for the patient having the wrong procedure
Discuss the case with your educational supervisor but do not identify the patient or consultant involved
Report the consultant to the General Medical Council
Speak to the clinical director for cardiology regarding what you have seen
Tell the consultant you saw what happened and you will inform the clinical director if he does not also pay you
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in cardiology at a large teaching hospital. On the morning ward round, the consultant notices they accidentally performed a balloon angioplasty the day before on a patient's left oblique marginal artery rather than their right oblique marginal. The consultant asks everyone not to mention anything to the patient and that they would deal with it later. You later see the consultant offering money to one of their consultant colleagues to change the operative records to indicate that the correct procedure had been performed.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
The correct order, from most to least appropriate, is DACBE.

To answer this question you must take into account two factors, patient safety and the risks to both the patient who has had the wrong procedure and other patients of this consultant and the behaviour of this consultant in response to their mistake. The best option is to speak to the clinical director. They can speak to the patient and ensure they do not come to further harm as well as dealing with the consultant in question.

Completing an incident form will achieve both of these objectives but in a less timely manner. Incident forms (or Datix forms) allow an incident affecting patient safety to be formally recorded and brought to the attention of managerial staff to prevent it from happening again. The forms are sent to multiple members of managerial staff including the clinical director, charge nurse for the ward and hospital administrators. However, it can take days for this to be actioned and in this time the patient that has had the wrong procedure is at risk, as are other patients being treated by the same consultant.

Reporting the consultant to the General Medical Council (GMC) is the next best option. The GMC have the power to investigate the incident and put sanctions on the consultant and the hospital if they find wrongdoing. However, a GMC investigation is slow and likely to risk further patients coming to harm before an outcome is decided. It can take months before a doctor being investigated by the GMC has any conditions placed on their practice and in this time they may pose a risk to further patients.

Discussing the case anonymously with your educational supervisor (ES) is less helpful as without identifiable information, your ES is unable to do anything. You should avoid recording patient identifiable information when undertaking reflections but in this case, a patient is at risk, so it would be appropriate to share the details with your ES as they could speak to the clinical director on your behalf and ensure the matter is dealt with. Without doing so, the consultant involved is free to continue practising and may harm patients.

Telling the consultant to pay you in exchange for not reporting his behaviour is blackmail. It is both illegal and risks further patients coming to harm by allowing the consultant to continue their practice.

title: GMC: Leadership and management for all doctors - Working with colleagues
body:
As with all aspects of medicine, the fundamental principle remains the same; make the patient your first concern. The purpose of this guidance is to allow the effective functioning of the clinical team to allow patient care to be done safely and smoothly, to the highest standards.

Leadership

The recommendations on leadership emphasise the importance of working within a multidisciplinary team. They specifically mention that other team members in leadership positions must be respected. This respect for non-medical staff in leadership roles is important.

For example, respecting the advice and leadership of an infection control nurse with regard to hand hygiene is important in making patients are protected from iatrogenic pathogen spread.

Respect for colleagues

If a colleague feels like they are not respected and not valued they may not feel able to speak up if they have concerns which may be relevant to patient safety. This is particularly important for junior and non-medical staff, and so it especially important to respect and value their skills and contribution to the team.

Additionally there is both a legal and moral responsibility to ensure that your colleagues have a safe and fair workplace. All doctors are responsible for facilitating this not only to avoid unpleasant behaviour themselves, but also by challenging others who act in a bullying or discriminatory manner. This is important both to comply with laws and policies on equality and diversity, but also to ensure patient safety as bullying and harassment will impair team cohesion and communication.


Communication within and between teams

The key message from this part of the guidance is that it is important that it is clear who is responsible for communicating what information both within members of the team, to other teams, and also to patients and carers. Mistakes are often made when team members assume that someone else will have passed on the relevant information and no one ends up doing it. Therefore whenever there is any doubt about whose job it is to pass on certain information, it is obligatory to check.

For example, if you expect that the nursing staff would have told you about any allergies the patient has, before prescribing it would be important to confirm with them that they have handed over all the relevant information.

Also it is important that teams cooperate more generally, including by having handovers. Proactive steps must be taken to clarify responsibilities and improve communication.

Responsibility and accountability

The most important duty of a doctor is to the dignity, safety and care of their patients. Again, it is important for doctors to ensure that it is clear exactly which staff members have which responsibilities, to ensure that these do not 'fall between the cracks' and get missed.

It is also important that you make these responsibilities clear to any staff in a team that you are leading.

When mistakes happen, it's often the result of system problems. For example it could be under-staffing putting decision making under higher strain, causing more mistakes. This happened in the Bawa-Garba case, the tragic death of a child from unrecognised sepsis on a day where a single doctor was trying to cover multiple wards.

Consequently, it is also the responsibility of doctors to engage in setting up and maintaining systems to make sure that risks are appropriately assessed and managed. Doctors are just as accountable for advice they give as a member of a decision making body, as they are for any other medical advice they offer.

options: Apologise for their distress
Advise them of the complaints procedure
Tell her to inform the nurse of her complaint
Inform her that this complaint would not be taken further
Involve your clinical supervisor
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in paediatrics. The mother of one of your patients approaches you one afternoon and says that she is very angry with one of the nurses caring for her son, saying that his care has not been 'up to scratch' and no matter what she says to the nurse, she never listens. She says that she now wants to make an official complaint. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
The best way to handle this situation would be to lead the mother into a quiet place to talk. You can then apologise for the distress caused and tell them where to go to fill in the complaint. Apologising for a patient or relatives distress in a difficult situation, or saying sorry that something has gone wrong, is not an admission of guilt and can help to open the channels of communication.

Informing your clinical supervisor is probably unnecessary but will not do any harm and therefore is the better option to come third.

Telling the mother to inform the nurse of her complaint is counter-productive - they have already spoken to her and it has not helped matters. It could make the situation worse by causing a conflict.

It would be incorrect to inform her that her complaint would not be taken further and therefore it is the worst option.

Apologising for a patient or relatives distress in a difficult situation, or saying sorry that something has gone wrong, is not an admission of guilt and can help to open the channels of communication.

Informing your clinical supervisor is probably unnecessary but will not do any harm and therefore is the better option to come third.

Telling the mother to inform the nurse of her complaint is counter-productive - they have already spoken to her and it has not helped matters. It could make the situation worse by causing a conflict.

It would be incorrect to inform her that her complaint would not be taken further and therefore it is the worst option.

title: Duty of candour
body:
All healthcare professionals must be honest when something has gone wrong. They must:
  • Tell the patient when something has gone wrong
  • Apologise to the patient (or carer or family member where appropriate)
  • Offer an appropriate resolution
  • Explain the potential short and long-term effects of the error

Important to note:
  • Saying sorry is not an admission of legal liability
  • The patient has a right to receive an apology from 'the most appropriate team member' - this will usually be the lead or accountable clinician
  • The process for reporting adverse incidents and near misses varies between different health organisations: you must follow your own organisations policy
  • The National Report d scheme
concept: Apologising for a patient or relatives distress is not an admission of guilt but can help to open the channels of communication in a difficult situation/complaint

options: Agree to not tell the partner
Tell the patient you have a responsibility to tell the partner
Offer to refer him to counselling service
Offer to speak to the patient and his partner together
Attempt to persuade the patient to tell his partner
questions: You are a GP registrar. Your next patient is a man who has recently been diagnosed with HIV. He used to be a heroin addict. You enquire about his partner and he states he has not told her, as he doesn't want her to leave him. He says they are using protection during sexual intercourse, so he thinks the risk of transmitting it is low. What is the most appropriate next step?
notes:
Attempting to persuade the patient to tell his partner (E) is the most appropriate option because the GMC advises that you make every effort to attempt to persuade the patient to tell those who are at risk of an infectious disease. It is important to note you cannot force the patient to disclose information and it is your responsibility, rather than the patient's, to disclose the information appropriately.

Telling the patient you have a responsibility to tell the partner (B) is the next most appropriate option, as you have 'a legal requirement to disclose information to the person at risk' (General Medical Council). It is also helpful to inform the patient what you are doing and that they will not be identified in the process.


Offering to speak to the patient and partner together can really help to relieve the pressure placed on the patient. Offering to refer him to a counselling service is the next appropriate option. Not disclosing the information is the least appropriate option as you have a duty to protect both the patient and the partner.
